habitat_description: Clouded salamanders are arboreal Plethodontids that occupy the coniferous forest and woodlands of OR and northern CA up to an elevation of around 1700m (Petranka 1998). Decaying stumps and logs typical of mature forested environments provide critical microhabitats for foraging and reproduction (Petranka 1998). Talus habitats within mature forests are also utilized for refugia (Petranka 1998, Corn and Bury 1991, Whitaker et al. 1986). The species is tolerant of recently burned forests and/or logging operations and may persist in these areas for up to a decade post harvest/burn provided suitable downed materials are left on site (Petranka 1998, Bury and Corn 1988, McKenzie and Storm 1970, Welsh and Lind 1988, 1991). Short rotations and "clean" harvest practices may decrease populations (Petranka 1998, Corn and Bury 1991). Wake and Jackman (1999) determined that populations in Northern CA south of the South Fork Smith river (and disjunctally, British Columbia) are genetically distinct and therefore identified a new species A. vagrans - Wandering salamander.
